paragraphs.text: Let's recruit academically gifted students from poor neighborhoods the same way we seek out star athletes.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: A recent report , according to Reuters, finds that "more than 3,000 students at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill received credit for fake classes over an 18-year period as part of a program that allowed many of them to remain eligible to play sports."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: But college sports scandals, like the one at North Carolina, are missing the point
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We should not be focusing on how the university broke the rules of college sports for almost 20 years by sending thousands of athletes to no-show classes to keep players eligible for play
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We should not even be asking whether the University of South Carolina and several other NCAA schools should guarantee four-year, "full cost of attendance" scholarships
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The real question is far more basic
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Why do so many colleges treat their star athletes better than their star students?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The comparison between how colleges treat athletes and high performing, low- income students is particularly revealing
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Student athletes are sought out
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: once identified they are actively recruited
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: admission comes with generous scholarships
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: once admitted students are pampered with better housing, free or subsidized food and special college counseling to help them adjust to college life
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: High performing, low-income students, in contrast, take out loans, engage in work-study programs and, once admitted, are left largely to fend for themselves
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We simply aren't doing enough to help academically gifted students who have financial need to offset the challenges of attending college
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: First generation college goers, attending schools far away from home and family, are often quite fragile
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As a result, the smart-but-poor struggle
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Only 59% of children from low-income households scoring in the top quartile on standardized tests go on to graduate from a 4-year college
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: while
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: 77% of children with similar scores but from wealthy families earn bachelor's degrees
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Worse, fully 17% of the top quartile of poor kids do not even apply to college
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Recruited Tar Heel athletes have it far easier
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Many factors contribute to this disparity
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: one of the most significant obstacles preventing high-achieving, low-income students from attaining their full potential is they exist in isolation in high school
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They do their part in school but are held back because they aren't identified and given support and guidance they need
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: There is no football coach or athletic counselor for these kids
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: they are on their own to develop a college selection strategy, navigate the maze of loan forms and develop a college budget
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Ironically, the way big-time college athletes are recruited offers solutions to address this problem
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We should seek out talented students from poor backgrounds the way athletics coaches search for high school athletes
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Coaches know part of their job is to find and cultivate talent
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: so
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: they send scouts to take in countless high school games looking for the next Tom Brady
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Admissions counselors often visit schools in wealthy suburbs
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: where most of the best students are college-bound anyway
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: How often do they visit schools in impoverished areas looking for the next Sonia Sotomayor?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: What if colleges had academic scouts to scour science fairs, mathematics competitions, art shows, and school plays seeking out the super smart, highly-diligent, poor kid?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Star athletes are also celebrated by their local media and ranked in nationwide publications
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They go from small-town heroes to catching the attention of the best athletic programs in the country
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: There is nothing comparable for the smart kid
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We are a long way from the revenge of the nerds
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Half the high schools in this country don't even have college counselors
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: where they do exist, the quality provided is often abysmal
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: either because the counselors have enormous caseloads or lack the resources and experience
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: For example
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: when I was Schools Chancellor, one New York high school had a single college counselor for 2,000 students
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Coaches also recruit by inviting potential applicants to make"official visits" paid for by the college
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which can include transportation, daily meals, a room to stay in during visits, even entertainment expenses
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: For many low-income, academically-gifted students, a paid college visit, especially one catered to their academic interests, is completely out of reach
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Until the recent initiative led by Bloomberg Philanthropies and the College Board, the application fee itself was a barrier
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Do we really want to tell students that catching balls is more important than acing tests?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Consider NFL Hall of Famer Jerry Rice, for years an undiscovered talent
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: He excelled but failed to gain attention from the best football programs like Ohio State or Oklahoma
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: So he attended Mississippi Valley State University, where he was finally recognized and went on to have one of the best football careers of all time
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: What if he had never picked up a ball?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: what if today we fail to recognize academic talent in poor neighborhoods, never developing the whiz kids?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: What if Albert Einstein had become an accountant or Neal DeGrasse Tyson a telephone repairman?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We do not need to end sports scholarships to address this issue
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: we just need to level the playing field
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: By placing athletics ahead of academics, however
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: many colleges are making profoundly poor choices
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The cost to our society of unrealized academic potential is unfathomable
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: My organization was founded by a legendary sportsman, Jack Kent Cooke
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: who knew there was too much untapped potential in the nation's young people
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: He left the bulk of a fortune from owning the Redskins to start the largest academic scholarship foundation in America
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: to find low-income, exceptional students who beat the odds
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: A fortune built on sports is dedicated to promoting academic stars
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The NCAA could learn something
paragraphs.label: assumption
